title: linear algebra - Is there a method to find a vector that optimizes a Rayleigh quotient over a subspace?
body: Let $M\in\mathbb{C}^{n\times n}$ be an arbitary Hermitian matrix and let $E$ be a subspace of $\mathbb{C}^n$ . Is there a method to find vectors $y,z\in E$ such that $$\dfrac{y^*My}{y^*y}=\sup_{x\in E\\ x\neq0}\dfrac{x^*Mx}{x^*x}\mbox{ and }\dfrac{z^*Mz}{z^*z}=\inf_{x\in E\\ x\neq0}\dfrac{x^*Mx}{x^*x}\hspace{3mm}?$$ If $E=\mathbb{C}^n$ then $x$ and $y$ will be any eigenvector of $M$ corresponding to the largest and smallest eigenvalues of $M$ respectively, so the method to find them is standard. How to find $y$ and $z$ when $E$ is a proper subspace of $\mathbb{C}^n$ with $\dim(E)>1$ ? linear-algebra matrices eigenvalues Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jun 22, 2020 at 18:46 asked Jun 17, 2020 at 19:58 Chilote 636 6 6 silver badges 10 10 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 4 $\begingroup$ Is there any reason you can't choose a basis of $E$, write $M$ in that basis, and proceed according to standard methods? $\endgroup$ Neal –  Neal 2020-06-17 20:40:05 +00:00 Commented Jun 17, 2020 at 20:40 $\begingroup$ @Neal could you please be a little more specific? I must be blind because I do not see a natural approach to this problem. $\endgroup$ Chilote –  Chilote 2020-06-17 21:58:49 +00:00 Commented Jun 17, 2020 at 21:58 $\begingroup$ If you have a subspace then you can find a basis. What's the problem? $\endgroup$ kodlu –  kodlu 2020-06-17 22:49:59 +00:00 Commented Jun 17, 2020 at 22:49 1 $\begingroup$ Pick a basis $e_i$ of $E$, let $N$ be the $\dim(E)\times\dim(E)$ matrix with $N_{ij} = M(e_i,e_j)$. Then extremize the Rayleigh quotient of $N$ over $E$. By construction this will yield the extremal values of the Rayleigh quotient of $M$ over $E$. $\endgroup$ Neal –  Neal 2020-06-18 13:27:37 +00:00 Commented Jun 18, 2020 at 13:27 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
